Is the written word in our country/world being corrupted by such technological advances as e-mail, cell phones with text messaging, instant messaging, and the general lack of the need to write anything lengthy using correct grammar? In my opinion, it is. We take too many shortcuts. It's too easy to just hit the spell check button on our computers; to bow to every whim of the little green and red lines under words in Microsoft word without understanding why those lines are there. Many people my age don't read for fun anymore. Books have been replaced by 2 hour long pieces of Hollywood, and by XBoxes, Nintendos, and the like. Is the written word in our country failing?

 Language is in a continuous state of flux: linguistic conventions are never permanently secure. If we compare the anarchy, or individualism, of spelling in say Shakespeare's time with our (relatively) fixed rules, we might conclude that we are living in a "silver age" of linguistic correctness.

 thy addition. (A Liberal.)
 
 Now that would liven up the debates. Quotes from King Lear.

 Methinks that thou dost protest too loudly. Ah yes, 'tis a fine day when the spoken melodies that constitute daily speech from yore do come winging back upon whatever flight of fancy dare beckon them; I find it most scintillating and enlivening of the faculties to bear hearing to such phrases. Why, in this meagre publishing of mine own creation, I believe that I hath stimulated all of the right parts of that flighty ally whom some might call my brain. But fear not, for though it might be a flighty ally, a most conniving and cunning enemy it is as well. Though some of you, upon reading these texts, might yawn and gape, as if trying to prod that large expanse between your ears to give some clue as to our arcane and esoteric meanings, give not up on guesswork and happenstance! Abolish the travesty of the dreaded "txt speak" and "leet speak", if not for the good of grammar, then to prevent the damnation of man!

 I did not know this until I looked it up in Halliday's "Shakespeare Companion": but "an eater of broken meats" is an insult of social position which indicates that the (inferior) person eats other people's left-overs. 
 
 It's a bit of Elizabethan slang put into Kent's malicious remarks to Oswald.
Dono

There is no end to the solecisms that affront the punctilious lover of the English language. Sentences that end with a preposition; split infinitives; not knowing the difference between its and it's; plurals such as bananas written as banana's; the there/their absurdity; the verb to imply confused with the verb to infer; etc., etc. 
 
 I could go on and on - but it would be to no avail. There is no escaping the "fact" that prescriptive usage cannot be reconciled with the continuous change which a living language must accommodate.

 Are you sure? In dictionary.com, the 3rd definition of "object(s)" is: The purpose, aim, or goal of a specific action or effort: the object of the game.
 
 To me, that seems to fit just fine.
 
 I realize that languages tend to change. But it has been proven throughout history that as languages change, their writing system gets progressively more advanced, somehow making it from cavewritings to the grammatical language we have today. How many people when writing emails try to make sure they use correct grammar, sentence structure, and punctuation? Who does that when they use instant messenger services? How often does the average American pick up a pen and actually write a letter, or just write for that matter. Our language is part of our culture, and in my eyes, through the shortcuts we so easily find, we are corrupting our own language. Students in my school hate writing papers and have a hard time writing them. It's fine to talk any way you like, but...can you put it on paper, that's the real test of the grasp on your language.

It IS saying what you mean, unless you try and apply mathematical logic to language. Are you going to start complaining that inflammable should mean the opposite of flammable now? A double negative in English simply means emphasising the negative, not negating it.
Phunting

No it isn't. I've got no apples. If I haven't got 'no apples', then surely I have apples.

Alan Ryan

Two negatives cancel each other and produce an affirmative. The correct meaning of "Nobody didn't go" is that everybody went. It is not "intellectual snobbery" to remark that a double negative is a grammatical blunder unlikely to occur in educated speech or writing.
Phunting
That's a much better example than any I came up with, thanks!
Jo Bennett

Two negatives cancel each other and produce an affirmative. The correct meaning of "Nobody didn't go" is that everybody went. It is not "intellectual snobbery" to remark that a double negative is a grammatical blunder unlikely to occur in educated speech or writing.

 
 It is only a grammatical blunder because a bunch of victorians decided it should be. It has for a long time been an accepted part of dialect speech. The double negative need not cancel out anymore than the prefix "in" must always mean "not".
Alan Ryan

Whether the double negative "matters", depends on whether you're talking about idiomatic English in which it might not signify if you violate logic and end up saying the opposite of what you mean, or whether you have formal English in mind and wish to avoid ambiguity. 
 
 More technically, it also depends on whether you take a descriptive or a prescriptive view of grammar: I prefer the latter view.

There is no ambiguity because no-one, other than the pedantic deliberately trying to misconstrue meaning, could ever take the double negative to mean anything other than the emphatic negative.

 The differences in spelling that are recorded in Webster's American and Oxford English dictionaries are not really a cause for concern: I don't mind writing (say) the American word "offense" instead of "offence", or spelling "endeavour" as "endeavor", etc. But it has become fashionable to speak disrespectfully of grammar - as if its rules are the linguistic baggage of a bygone age. Unless the conventions of "good" grammar are observed, those who wish to write or to speak clearly and agreeably, will not succeed in doing so. 
 
 My visits to the US have given me the impression that "ordinary" Americans are usually more articulate and speak better English than the man on the Clapham bus.

This thread is very interesting IMHO.
 
 I don't see regional differences in pronunciation and annunciation as a major issue in fact I think it makes living in this Country(UK) very interesting.  We Scots have butchered the English Language far more than our American brethren in fact we have almost created our own dialect of English called Scots or Lowland Scots(pronounced 'Lallans') look to the poems and songs of Rabbie Burns for a good example of Lallan Scots.
 
 
Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face,
 Great chieftain o' the puddin'-race!
 Aboon them a' ye tak yer place,
 Painch, tripe, or thairm:
 Weel are ye wordy o' a grace
 As lang's my airm.,

 Nobody has yet made the connection between accent and social class - which is always a "hot topic" in England. It has been said (was it Orwell ?) that no sooner does an Englishman open his mouth than another Englishman immediately despises him.
 
 The toffs employ hundreds of verbal traps to sort out the patrician wheat from the plebeian chaff. Here's an instance: how would you pronounce the name "Featherstonehaugh" ? Unless you say "Fanshaw", you drop a terrible clanger, apparently.
Clive14

The toffs employ hundreds of verbal traps to sort out the patrician wheat from the plebeian chaff. Here's an instance: how would you pronounce the name "Featherstonehaugh" ? Unless you say "Fanshaw", you drop a terrible clanger, apparently.
How is this different from us catching American tourists out by pronouncing Leicestershire as "lestersheer" or the poeple of Norfolk catching everyone out by pronouncing Wymondham as "windum"?
Alan Ryan

You will find "eccentric" pronunciations of place names all over England. What I had in mind were the distinctions of class which are enshrined in some English personal names, and the differences in usage which are (or have been) associated with social status. Another instance: the common or garden name Ralph, might be pronounced "Rafe" by a member of the "upper class".
 
 However, I not just talking about differences in pronunciation, because there is supposed to be a whole vocabulary by which the "U" is separated from the "non-U" use of English. According to Alan Ross, who is "credited" with the discovery of these differences, many words are loaded with a kind of social ballast which has the function of "placing" the individual within the social hierarchy.
Clive14

You will find "eccentric" pronunciations of place names all over England. What I had in mind were the distinctions of class which are enshrined in some English personal names, and the differences in usage which are (or have been) associated with social status. Another instance: the common or garden name Ralph, might be pronounced "Rafe" by a member of the "upper class".
Is Anthony, where the "th" is pronounced as "th" rather than "t", an example of this then? I'd always dismissed such people as being a pr*t, rather than being a toff.
 
 
However, I not just talking about differences in pronunciation, because there is supposed to be a whole vocabulary by which the "U" is separated from the "non-U" use of English. According to Alan Ross, who is "credited" with the discovery of these differences, many words are loaded with a kind of social ballast which has the function of "placing" the individual within the social hierarchy.
I'd agree with this, but for different reasons. We put 't's in the middle of words for example to distinguish plebs (who fail to pronounce them) from the educated (who do) for example ;)
Phunting

pronouncing Leicestershire as "lestersheer"
Or even more amusingly Ly-cester-sheer!
Phunting

I'd agree with this, but for different reasons. We put 't's in the middle of words for example to distinguish plebs (who fail to pronounce them) from the educated (who do) for example ;)
I think Alan is reffering to the distinctions in vocabulary listed by Ross as being U (Upper Class) or Non-U. Such as film and movie, pardon and sorry, hello and yo brethren whagwan blood!
billsco

How do you guys across the pond pronounce "forte"?
 
 I've discontinued using it since learning its proper pronunciation is one syllable, but saying it correctly only results in addling a listener. It's kind of taken the fun out of a once-fun word. I use "strength" or something equally boring instead.
Clive14

How do you guys across the pond pronounce "forte"?
The same as you: "fortey"
 
 
I've discontinued using it since learning its proper pronunciation is one syllable, but saying it correctly only results in addling a listener. It's kind of taken the fun out of a once-fun word. I use "strength" or something equally boring instead.
I prefer to take the view that dictionary writers are sometimes stuck too far up their own arses. It is incredibly conceited to ever claim a word has a correct pronunciation.
Jo Bennett

That link appears to list three possible pronunciations, the first of which appears to be the one I am familiar with, and is in two syllables. As far as I am concerned the correct pronunciation is the one in common use, as with theatre I have no intention of using the french pronunciation because a linguist in a mortar board says I should.
Alan Ryan

You cannot learn a foreign language without paying close attention to correct pronunciation: it is not conceited to pronounce "Paris" as "Paree" when in France - though it would be affected to do so in English. 
 
 But there are many words borrowed from other languages which are still pronounced in accordance with their foreign roots: it's mere iconoclasm to pretend that dictionaries, which are necessary guides to correct meanings and pronunciation, are lists of conceits.
Phunting

I prefer to take the view that dictionary writers are sometimes stuck too far up their own arses. It is incredibly conceited to ever claim a word has a correct pronunciation.
To an extent. But I think some words have definite mispronunciations, such as Leicestershire as we previously spoke about.
 
 Off topic, I see you quoted Bassman's little gem in your signature, I almost did too but you beat me to it.
 
 "It's spelt Raymond Luxury-Yacht but it's pronounced Throat-Wobbler Mangrove."
Clive14

You cannot learn a foreign language without paying close attention to correct pronunciation
I'd be interested to know which of the hundreds of regional variations in how many words in the English language are pronounced is the "correct" one in your view.
 
 
But there are many words borrowed from other languages which are still pronounced in accordance with their foreign roots: it's mere iconoclasm to pretend that dictionaries, which are necessary guides to correct meanings and pronunciation, are lists of conceits.
I did not claim that a dictionary is a list of conceits, but it is a conceit to claim there is just one correct pronounciation of a word: especially when the claimed correct pronounciation is an out-dated minority-use pronounciation.
Alan Ryan

I prefer to take the view that dictionary writers are sometimes stuck too far up their own arses. It is incredibly conceited to ever claim a word has a correct pronunciation.

 I take this to be a rhetorical flourish: I can't believe you don't see what you call "correct" pronunciation, is simply articulating the sounds necessary for intelligible communication.
 
 Is it a "conceit" (for example, and there are lots of others) to say "chimney" rather than mispronounce this word as "chimley" ?
 
 I don't set myself up as an authority on pronunciation, and I am willing to be guided by the dictionary on matters of correct pronunciation as well as meanings. I don't object to regional variations of accent. 
 
 It's very easy to cast anyone who defends a prescriptive view of language in the role of a pedant. But, I emphasise, that without regularity in matters of pronunciation, we should quickly become unintelligible to each other.
Clive14

Alan,
 
 How do you pronounce grass, glass, bath, path? Is pronouncing each of these words with a hard "a" (eg barth) the right or wrong pronunciation?
 
 In parts of Hertfordshire, the word "pint" is pronounced "point". Do all of these people mispronounce, or is it just a regional accent?
 
 "simply articulating the sounds necessary for intelligible communication" is another way of using a word - and saying it - in a fashion that will be understood by your audience. If no one you are talking to has ever encountered someone pronouncing "forte" and "fort", then you are failing to achieve intelligible communication if you use "fort".
 
 So no, I'm not endulging in a rhetorical flourish, I'm being serious when I suggest that it is conceited to claim a word has a single correct pronunciation.
 
 When a dictionary records both past and present uses of a word, it is doing its job.
 When a dictionary advises on common use versus precise use in certain circumstances (acute, chronic, awesome, theory and insect being examples) then it is doing its job.
 When a dictionary prescribes a fixed correct usage that ignores or runs contrary to common use then its no longer doing its job. Instead it is taking on the role of being the guardian of some arbitary language state rather than being a record of usage. It has failed its job and become conceited.
Alan Ryan

Alan,
 
 When a dictionary records both past and present uses of a word, it is doing its job.
 When a dictionary advises on common use versus precise use in certain circumstances (acute, chronic, awesome, theory and insect being examples) then it is doing its job.
 When a dictionary prescribes a fixed correct usage that ignores or runs contrary to common use then its no longer doing its job. Instead it is taking on the role of being the guardian of some arbitary language state rather than being a record of usage. It has failed its job and become conceited.

 I'm not concerned with regional accents which play variations on the theme of "correct English": what I'm talking about is making yourself understood despite phonetic inconsistency.
 
 To illustrate: here's a small collection of familiar words: 
 
 bough, tough, cough, Lough Swilly
 plough, rough, trough, 
 Slough, Brian Clough, dough 
 
 There has to be some way of guiding people through a minefield like this, and the dictionary provides it. In other words, unless you prepared to admit there is a standard or correct pronunciation, you will make mistakes in usage.
 
 If your name was Clive Clough, I expect you would correct anyone who called you Mr Clough rhyming with Slough, instead of Mr Cluff ? I should not consider you to be conceited if you insisted on the "cluff" pronunciation.
Phunting

On the subject of pronunciation. I was corrected on my phonetic pronunciation of Junta on Friday and after looking into it found that interestingly the correct British pronunciation does appear to be the bastardised phonetic form. However "hunta", being true to the Spanish, is apparently the American pronunciation.
 
 Well I found it interesting anyway... :p
Dono

I once met a yankee who thought y'all, a second person plural pronoun that we in the southern U.S. use often, was a 2-masted sailboat.
 Dono
Alan Ryan

I once met a yankee who thought y'all, a second person plural pronoun that we in the southern U.S. use often, was a 2-masted sailboat.
 Dono

 There's a song, "Y'all come, Y'all come" (Y'all come to see us now and then) recorded by Dolly Parton which, I think, affirms the hospitality of the southern states ? Or is this use of y'all a kind of cultural myth ?
 
 I've never been further south than Richmond, Virginia, and I don't recall hearing the expression there. But it's not really considered "deep south" up there, is it ?
doG

I doubt 'txt speech' will stay for more than a decade or two.

 That long? How long will it be before we don't txt msg anymore because we simply speak and the computer's speech to text engine writes our message for us? With the exponential rate of the exponential growth of technology we are seeing, another decade would surprise me...
Phantos

The only problem with that is, is you then lose the privacy you had with the ability to just push a couple of buttons. I can see where it would be helpful sometimes, but other times, I'm not sure I would want others to hear what I'm dictating to some device. Besides, how will we do smilies then!? emoticon_rolleyes
